After a detailed workup, he is diagnosed with early-stagehepatocellular carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver. The surgeon decides to perform a lefthemi-hepatectomy. questions.explanation: In the left hemi-hepatectomy (also called left hepatectomy) the segments marked as II, III, and IVshould be removed.Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver isdivided into eight segments. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, andlymphatic drainage. questions.question: What is the most common anomaly of the hepatic artery?

options.A: Independent origin of the right and left hepatic arteries from the cealic axis
options.B: Replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesentric artery

questions.explanation: The most common anomaly of the hepatic artery is replaced right hepatic artery arising from thesuperior mesenteric artery.Normally, the common hepatic artery gives off the right and left hepatic arteries. A middle hepaticartery branches off from the proximal left hepatic artery.The replaced right hepatic artery directly supplies the right lobe of the liver.Surgical significance:In individuals with replaced right hepatic artery, the diameter of the common hepatic artery issmaller. In liver transplant recipients, this can be a cause for the increased incidence ofcomplications such as thrombosis.Whereas, replaced right hepatic artery is a beneficial variant for donors undergoing donation ofthe right lobe of the liver. The replaced right hepatic artery provides a longer and larger graft thusreducing chances of thrombosis.680Normal hepatic artery vasculatureRight hepatic arteryCystic arteryGastro-duodenal arteryLeft hepatic arteryROMARROWSplenic arteryCeliac trunkSuperior mesenteric arteryReplaced right hepatic arteryWReplaced right hepatic artery-Superior mesenteric arteryOMARROW

questions.question: The free hepatic venous pressure(FHVP) and wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) of apatient, with suspected portal hypertension, are measured. How will the hepatic venous667pressure gradient (HVPG) be determined from these values?-
questions.explanation: Hepatic Venous Pressure Gradient is measured by subtracting Free Hepatic Venous Pressure fromWedged Hepatic Venous Pressure.HVPG = WHVP - FHVP==Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the pressure gradient between the portal vein and theinferior vena cava (IVC). It is a measure of portal venous pressure. It can quantify the degree ofportal hypertension due to sinusoidal resistance to blood flow.The most accurate method of determining portal hypertension is by measuring HVPG. The mostcommonly used procedure involves placing a balloon catheter in the hepatic vein after a jugularvein puncture. The free hepatic venous pressure (FHVP) is measured with the balloon deflated,and the wedged hepatic venous pressure (WHVP) with the balloon inflated to occlude the hepatic681vein.

questions.question: Which of the following values indicate a normal portal venous pressure?
questions.explanation: The normal portal venous pressure is 5 to 10 mmHg.Normal portal blood flow is 1 to 1.5 L/minute.Hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) is the difference between the wedge and free hepaticvenous pressure, which is 1 to 5 mmHg.HVPG interpretation:• Normal HVPG is between 1 and 5 mmHg.• Portal hypertension is present if the HVPG is °6 mmHg.• Portal hypertension typically becomes clinically significant when the HVPG is °10 mmHg, atwhich point varices may develop.• HVPG 12 mmHg, patients are at risk for variceal bleeding and the development of ascites.

questions.question: All of the following are post-hepatic causes for portal hypertension, except
questions.explanation: Splenomegaly is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. Sarcoidosis and primary biliarycholangitis are presinusoidal intrahepatic causes of portal hypertension.Portal hypertension occurs when the pressure in the portal vein increases due to either increasedresistance to blood flow secondary to fibrosis, active vasoconstriction, or hyperdynamic systemiccirculation.

questions.question: A patient who is a known case of chronic pancreatitis is diagnosed with splenic veinthrombosis. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

options.B: USG abdomen showed normal liver and an enlarged spleen.
options.D: TIPSS is done as part of treatment

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a case of splenic vein thrombosis which can cause left-sidedportal hypertension. It is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension. It is managedby splenectomy.Splenic vein thrombosis can be due to pancreatic inflammation or neoplasms (acute or chronicpancreatitis, pseudocysts, and carcinomas) that extend outside the pancreas and invades thesplenic vein. This causes increased pressure in the splenic vein leading to the formation ofcollaterals and ultimately gastric variceal hemorrhage (not esophageal varices).Normal liver function tests, normal portal venous pressures, and splenomegaly are thedistinguishing features from other forms of portal hypertension. The portal vein pressures remainnormal as there is no obstruction of the hepatic venous vasculature.Diagnosis is done by gastroscopy, liver function tests, ultrasound examination (with doppler), andcontrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. Treatment includes splenectomy and management ofthe primary pancreatic pathology.682Portal veinRightgastric veinSuperiormesentericveinLeft-sided portal hypertensionSplenic veinOMARROWGastric varicesEnlarged spleen-ThrombusGastro-epiploic vein

questions.question: 668An elderly patient with chronic black tarry stools underwent an upper GI endoscopy. Gastricmucosa appeared as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?GROVER
questions.explanation: The image shows the snake-skin appearance of the gastric mucosa, which is seen in cases of portalhypertensive gastropathy.Portal hypertensive gastropathy is characterized by the diffuse dilation of the mucosal andsubmucosal venous plexus of the stomach associated with overlying gastritis.Option A: Gastric antral vascular ectasia (GAVE) also known as watermelon stomach is asignificant cause of acute or chronic gastrointestinal blood loss in the elderly, characterizedendoscopically by watermelon stripes. It is associated with heterogeneous medical conditions,including hepatic, cardiac, and renal diseases.683DAILYROUNDSOption C: Hypoproteinemic hypertrophic gastropathy also known as Menetrier's disease is a rare,acquired premalignant disease of the stomach characterized by massive gastric folds, little or noacid production, and excessive mucous production with resultant protein loss. The disorder isassociated with excessive secretion of transforming growth factor-alpha.Option D: Dieulafoy's lesion is a medical condition characterized by a large tortuous arteriole thaterodes and bleeds and occurs most commonly in the stomach wall.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding Budd-Chiari syndrome?

options.A: Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the patients
options.B: Doppler ultrasonography is the initial investigation of choice
options.C: It becomes clinically significant when one or more major hepatic veins are obstructed
options.D: Oral contraceptive use is a risk factor

questions.explanation: Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by theobstruction of hepatic venous outflow and it becomes clinically significant when two or moremajor hepatic veins are obstructed.684Types:• Primary Budd-Chiari syndrome: when the obstructive process involves an endoluminal venousthrombosis.• Secondary Budd-Chiari syndrome: when the veins are compressed or invaded by a neighboringlesion originating outside the vein.Most common presentation: ascites and abdominal discomfort.Risk factors include-Primary myeloproliferative disorders, anticardiolipin antibodies,hyperhomocysteinemia, and oral contraceptive use.Caudate lobe hypertrophy is seen in approximately 50% of the cases and it is because the caudatelobe drains directly into the IVC.Abdominal ultrasonography with color Doppler is the initial investigation of choice and candemonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepaticveins.The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent ofhepatic vein thrombus as well as measure inferior vena cava (IVC) pressures.

questions.question: A 43-year-old woman presented to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain anddistension for the past 3 months. Her past medical records show that she has a JAK2mutation and investigations revealed serum protein to be 3 g/dL and ascitic fluid protein tobe 1.5 g/dL. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.A: Anticoagulation is the mainstay of treatment669
options.B: Colour flow doppler is the initial investigation of choice
options.C: Surgical intervention is done in all cases
options.D: Ascites is a bad prognostic factor

questions.explanation: The above clinical scenario describes a case of late budd-chiari syndrome and surgicalinterventions are not done in all cases of budd chiari syndrome.SAAG = (serum albumin) – (ascitic fluid albumin)=(3) - (1.5) = 1.5g/dLAs SAAG is >1.1g/dL( 1.5g/dL) and ascitic fluid protein is < 2.5 g/dL, the most likely cause islate Budd-Chiari syndrome.Surgical interventions are done in those patients of Budd Chiarisyndrome who are not responding to medical therapy.Colour flow doppler is the initial investigation of choice.Treatment:• Initial treatment consists of medically managing the underlying disease process and preventingthe extension of the hepatic vein thrombosis through systemic anticoagulation.• The associated portal hypertension and ascites are managed in a manner similar to that in mostcirrhotic patients.• Radiologic and surgical intervention should be reserved for patients whose condition isnonresponsive to medical therapy. Percutaneous angioplasty and transjugular intrahepaticportosystemic shunt (TIPS), in combination with thrombolytic therapy, are the preferredstrategies to restore the outflow of blood from the liver.• Surgical shunting, particularly with the side-to-side portacaval shunt, turns the portal vein intoa hepatic outflow tract.Factors contributing to a bad prognosis in Budd-Chiari syndrome:685Involvement of all three hepatic veins and/or portal veinPresence of ascitesOlder age at the time of presentationHigh Child-Pugh scoreChronic disease at presentationNote: JAK2 mutation points to a possibility of polycythemia vera predisposing the patient tohypercoagulable states and the formation of thrombus anywhere in the body. From the serum andascitic protein values, we can calculate the SAAG (serum protein-ascitic protein).

questions.question: A patient comes with active variceal bleeding. Which of the following is not done?
questions.explanation: Platelet transfusion is not done in the case of active variceal bleeding unless coagulopathy isconfirmed as the cause. Platelet transfusions are indicated only in patients with a platelet count of<50,000/microL or in patients with evidence of microvascular bleeding.Variceal hemorrhage is a medical emergency. Varices usually present with the acuteonset large-volume haematemesis, the lower esophagus being the most common site for varicealbleeding.The sites for portosystemic anastomosis are:••• Left gastric vein to distal oesophageal veins: oesophageal and gastric variceal bleedingSuperior rectal veins to Middle and inferior rectal veins: hemorrhoids and rectal bleeding• Left branch of the portal vein to Periumbilical veins: caput-medusae• The right branch of the portal vein to retroperitoneal veins draining into azygos, hemiazygos,lumbar, intercostal, and phrenic veins•⚫ Omental and colonic veins near hepatic and splenic ■exures to Retroperitoneal veins nearhepatic and splenic exuresMedical management of variceal bleeding includes blood transfusion (option B) and drug therapywith somatostatin analogs like octreotide (option C). Short-term antibiotics like ceftriaxone areknown to decrease bacterial infection and increase survival.Surgical measures are preferred if medical management fails. They include balloon tamponade,endoscopic banding (option D), transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS),portosystemic shunts, splenectomy, and gastric revascularizationNote: Sugiura procedure is the non-shunt surgical management of refractory oesophageal varicealbleeding. It is a procedure of de-vascularizing the distal esophagus and stomach.686Management of acute variceal bleedingVariceal bleeding suspected based on historyAirway, Breathing, CirculationStart octreotide or vasopressin infusionMProphylactic antiboitics followed by upper Gl endoscopyVariceal bleeding confirmedEndoscopic band ligation (or sclerotherapy)YesBleeding stopped?No- Octeotide/vasopressin for 3-5 days- Antibiotics continued for 7 days- Repeat endoscopic bandingevery 10-14 days until eliminatedBalloon tamponade• Consider TIPS or surgical shuntif TIPS unavailable or failedMARROW

questions.question: A 56-year-old patient with intractable ascites underwent a procedure as shown below.Identify the procedure.MAOMARROW
questions.explanation: The image shows the transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt(TIPS) procedure with theviatorr device.The main indication of TIPS is for variceal bleeds not responding to medical or endoscopictreatment, and intractable ascites.The shunts are inserted under local anaesthetic, analgesia and sedation, using fluoroscopicguidance and ultrasonography. Via the internal jugular vein and superior venacava, a guidewire isinserted into a hepatic vein and through the hepatic parenchyma into a branch of the portal vein.The main early complication of this technique is the perforation of the liver capsule and the maincontraindication to TIPSS is portal vein occlusion.Shunts for Portal Hypertension:•Non- Selective Shunt- bowel and splenic blood is shunted• Linton shunt (proximal lienorenal shunt with splenectomy)• ECK fistula (portocaval shunt)• Mitra shunt (splenorenal shunt)• Selective Shunt- only splenic blood is shuntedWarren shunt (distal lienorenal shunt)•Inokuchi shunt687Shunts for Portal HypertensionIVOPVRVShuntIVCPVShuntLRVDistal Lienorenal(Warren shunt)2Proximal Lienorenalshunt with splenectomy(Linton Shunt)ARROPVShuntIVO3End-to-side PortocavalShunt (ECK Fistula)IVOLAVSide-to-side Lienorenalshunt without splenectomy(Mitra Shunt)IVC-Inferior Vena CavaLRV - Left Renal VeinPV - Portal VeinSV-Splenic VeinMARROW

questions.question: A patient with liver cirrhosis is scheduled to undergo a laparotomy for a perforated appendix.According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score, which of the following parameters will you notuse for this patient?
questions.explanation: Creatinine is not included in the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score or Child-Pugh scoring system.It is used to assess the surgical mortality of cirrhotic patients undergoing intra-abdominaloperations.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of MELD score?
questions.explanation: In MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score, urea is not one of the components.

questions.question: A 40-year-old male patient who was diagnosed with gangrenous appendix underwent anappendicectomy. On the second postoperative day, he developed fever, chills, jaundice, andright upper quadrant pain. Blood cultures revealed bacteremia and ultrasound abdomenrevealed multiple hepatic abscesses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In the setting of existing appendicitis, the above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis ofpylephlebitis (portal pyemia).Pylephlebitis is thrombophlebitis of the portal venous system. It is a rare but very seriouscomplication of intra-abdominal infections, such as gangrenous appendicitis, diverticulitis, etc. Itspreads to the portal circulation via the mesenteric vein.Clinical features are high fever, rigors, and jaundice and intrahepatic abscesses (often multiple)due to septicemia in the portal venous system. Treatment is with systemic antibiotics andpercutaneous drainage of hepatic abscesses.Option A: Peliosis hepatis is an uncommon vascular condition characterized by hemorrhagicdilatation of the hepatic sinusoids.Option C: Hepatic necrotic nodules are usually small, solitary lesions, mainly located under theliver capsule of the right lobe. It is characterized by a necrotic central core surrounded by a dense688hyalinized fibrotic capsule.Option D: Melioidosis is an infectious disease caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei characterisedby fever and multiple abscess formation in the lungs, liver, prostate, and spleen.

questions.question: A 60-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with right upper quadrant pain andjaundice for the past 5 days. CT abdomen revealed the following finding and cultures ofaspirate showed extensive bacterial growth. Which of the following is false regarding thiscondition?671

options.A: Anchovy sauce pus is seen on aspiration of abscess
options.B: Fever with chills is the most common presenting complaintEschericia coli and Klebsiella species are the most common organisms implicatedd) Ascending infection from the biliary tract is the most common route of spreadQuestion 17:Which of the following statements regarding investigations in a pyogenic liver abscess is true?a) X-Ray findings are diagnostic.b) USG shows hypoechoic lesion with poorly defined borders
options.C: Elevated ALP is the most common abnormal LFT.

questions.explanation: The given CT image shows cluster sign and the above clinical scenario is suggestive of pyogenicliver abscess. Anchovy sauce pus on aspiration is seen in amoebic liver abscess.Pyogenic liver abscess is a polymicrobial infection seen more commonly in the elderly andimmunocompromised. Ascending infection from the biliary tree (ascending suppurativecholangitis) is the most common route of spread.The portal vein is the second most common source of infection leading to pylephlebitis(thrombophlebitis of the portal venous system causing portal pyemia) secondary to diverticulitis,appendicitis, pancreatitis, etc.Organism:• Most common in western countries: Escherichia coli• Most common in Asian countries: Klebsiella pneumoniae• Most common in children suffering from the chronic granulomatous disease: StaphylococcusMost common in gas-forming abscess: KlebsiellaOrder of affected lobe: Right lobe (75%) > left lobe (20%) > caudate lobe (5%). Right lobepredilection might be due to preferential laminar blood flow.

questions.question: A healthy 55-year-old man presented with a 1-week history of fevers, chills, right upperquadrant tenderness, and hepatomegaly. CT was suggestive of a pyogenic liver abscess.Which of the following statements regarding management is true?

options.A: Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is first line
options.B: Percutaneous drainage is not routinely done
options.C: Open drainage is done with T-tube placement
options.D: Resection of the affected lobe is the treatment of choice672

questions.explanation: Empiric IV antibiotic therapy is the first-line treatment for pyogenic liver abscess.Percutaneous drainage using a pigtail catheter is done routinely. It helps in the slowdecompression of a cyst with viscous contents. It also has a lesser chance ofdislodgement. Drainage tube catheter is placed under US/CT guidance into the liver abscess.Surgical drainage using a laparoscopic or open approach is tried only when antibiotic therapy andpercutaneous drainage fails. Open drainage is becoming less common at present. Liver resectionis only occasionally required in severe hepatic destruction.Pigtail catheter:690

questions.question: A 35-year-old daily wage laborer presented with fever and abdominal pain for the past 1 week.Laboratory investigations showed anti-amoebic antibodies and CT abdomen showed thefollowing. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.B: Anchovy sauce pus is seen on aspiration

questions.explanation: The patient most likely has an amoebic liver abscess. It is more common in males than females(10:1).Risk factors include:• Males, 20-40 yearsof age• Heavy alcohol consumption - liver becomes more susceptible• Travel to an endemic area• Poverty and cramped living conditions• Impaired host immunity.• Colonic infectionThe most common sites for amoebic liver abscesses are liver and paracaecal areas. The aspirateshows a characteristic anchovy sauce pus.Even though this disease process is secondary to a colonic infection, the presence of diarrhoea isunusual.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding amoebic liver abscess is false?

options.A: Culture of the aspirate is positive.
options.B: The diagnosis is based on the detection of antiamebic antibodies.
options.C: Management mainly consists of conservative treatment with metronidazole.

questions.explanation: The culture of the amoebic abscess is usually sterile or negative.The most useful laboratory evaluation is the measurement of circulating anti-amoebic antibodies,by enzyme immunoassay. The antibody can be present because of prior infection, and hence,detection of Entamoeba histolytica lectin antigen in the serum and liver abscess pus is more usefulfor acute infections than chronic infection.Nuclear medicine studies, such as gallium scanning or technetium (99mTc) liver scans, can behelpful in differentiating pyogenic from amebic abscesses because amebic abscesses typically donot contain leukocytes and therefore do not light up on these scans.The mainstay of treatment for amebic abscesses is metronidazole (750 mg orally, three times dailyfor 10 days), which is curative. Luminal agents such as iodoquinol, paromomycin, and diloxanidefuroate can be administered into the cysts.

questions.question: 673Which of the following are not indications for percutaneous aspiration in a patient with asuspected amoebic liver abscess?

options.C: Failure to respond to medical therapy

questions.explanation: Percutaneous aspiration should be performed in amoebic liver abscess more than 5 cm.Indications for percutaneous aspiration in amoebic liver abscess are:•Large abscesses (>5 cm)• Lack of response to medical therapy (in 5 days)• Suspicion of superinfection691• Abscesses of the left lobe of the liver at risk for rupture into the pericardium• Uncertain diagnosisLaboratory investigations may reveal similar complete blood cell count and liver function testabnormalities in patients with amoebic liver abscesses and pyogenic liver abscesses. An elevatedserum alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level is seen in both and is not specific.

questions.question: In the given image, which of the following structures are matched correctly?
questions.explanation: F-Endocyst and H-Hydatid sand are matched correctly.Structure of the hydatid cyst (Cross section)Pericyst (blood vesselsand fibroblasts)Ectocyst (acellular,laminated, hyaline layer)Daughter cystHydatid sandOMARROWBroodcapsulesScolexStalk-Endocyst(germinal layer)Hydatid fluidHydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species offlatworms. Its life cycle consists of sheep and dogs as hosts. Humans are accidental hosts.A hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrouscapsule called pericyst that is derived from the host tissue.The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst(inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in thepassage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In adefinitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts thesedevelop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle orstalk.The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts,which are an exact replica of the mother cysts. The freed brood capsules and scoleces present inthe hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

questions.question: A patient was incidentally found to have a fluid filled cyst in his liver when he underwent aUSG abdomen to check for renal calculi. It was later diagnosed as echinococcosis. Which ofthe following is false regarding this condition?

options.B: Rupture can lead to severe anaphylactic reaction674
options.D: Echinococcus multilocularis is the most common causative agent

questions.explanation: 692Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts, whileEchinococcus multilocularis and Echinococcus ligartus account for a small number of cases.Dogs are the definitive hosts of E. granulosus. Sheep are the usual intermediate hosts, andhumans are accidental intermediate hosts. Humans are end-stage hosts of the parasite since thereis no human to human transmission.The clinical presentation of a hydatid cyst is largely asymptomatic, until complications occur. Themost common presenting symptoms are abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and vomiting. The mostfrequent sign is hepatomegaly.Approximately 75% of hydatid cysts are located in the right lobe of the liver and are solitary.The life cycle of Echinococcus:Protoscolexfrom cystIngestion of cysts40(in organs)Scolex attachesto intestineAdult in small intestineDefinitive Host(dogs & other canidae)Intermediate Host(sheep, goats, swine, etc.)Ingestion of eggs(in feces)A2Embryonatedegg in feces44Infective StageHydatid cyst in liver, lungs, etc.Oncosphere hatches;penetrates intestinal wall= Diagnostic StageMultiple hydatid cysts:1213 14 15 16693

questions.question: A young villager presents to the clinic with abdominal pain for the past 1 month. He mentionsthat he keeps sheep inside the house. On examination, you feel a firm mass in the righthypochondrium and a hepatic hydatid cyst is suspected. Which of the following investigationshave the highest sensitivity in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows thepresence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity todemonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts.The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have asensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice.The Casoni test is a skin test used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease and involves the intradermalinjection of 0.25 ml of sterilised fluid from hydatid cysts/human cysts. A wheal response occurringat the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive (immediate hypersensitivity). Thetest is positive in less than 50% of patients with hydatid disease elsewhere in the body andfalse-positive results are also common so it's not preferred.Note: First/Initial imaging test is USG, best imaging test is CT scanCT scan showing multiple hydatid cysts with detached wavy membranes:

questions.explanation: The given imaging finding on CECT is suggestive of class CE3A hydatid cyst disease of the liver.The ideal management for type CE3A hydatid cyst of dimension >5cm is Albendazole therapy400 mg twice daily and PAIR (puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspiration) therapy.Classification of CE based on ultrasound imagingTypeUltrasound featuresActive cystCE1Univesicular fluid collectionCE2Honeycomb appearance:Multivesicular fluid collection with daughter cysts separated byseptaeTransitional cystCE3ACE3BInactive/dead cystCE4CE5Water lily sign:Fluid collection with detached membraneDaughter cysts present in a solid matrixCysts in a heterogeneous matrix with no daughter cystsSolid cystic wall697CE: cystic echinococcosis; PAIR: puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspirationWhen PAIR is contraindicated (CE2, CE3B), surgical resection involving laparoscopic or opencomplete cystectomy with instillation of a scolicidal agent is preferred and is usually curative. questions.question: Which of the following is a contraindication for performing PAIR technique in hydatid cystdisease?

options.B: Pregnant woman with CE1 hydatid cyst
options.D: Cyst > 5 cm in different liver segments

questions.explanation: A hydatid cyst with honeycomb appearance (CE2) is a contraindication for PAIR(Puncture-Aspiration-Injection-Reaspiration).PAIR is unlikely to be successful in CE2 due to the presence of multiple internal septa.The PAIR technique is performed using either ultrasound or computed tomography (CT)guidance.It involves aspiration of the cyst contents via a special cannula, followed by injection of ascolicidal agent for at least 15 minutes, and then reaspiration of the cystic contents. This isrepeated until the return is clear. An initial course of albendazole is administered before theprocedure.When PAIR is contraindicated, surgical resection involving laparoscopic or open completecystectomy with instillation of a scolicidal agent is preferred and is usually curative. If completecystectomy is not possible, then anatomic liver resection can be undertaken.698PAIRMdfor Hydatid cvatAspirationHeaspirationIDMARROW

The surgeon decides to perform a percutaneous aspiration, injection, andreaspiration (PAIR) of the cyst after a 6 cm single hydatid cyst was detected. All of thefollowing can be used as scolicidal agents in this procedure except?
questions.explanation: Formalin is not used as a scolicidal agent since it causes sclerosing cholangitis.Scolicidal agents (used to avoid dissemination of parasite during surgery):•Hypertonic saline• Cetrimide• Alcohol• Sodium hypochlorite• Povidone-iodine

questions.question: Which of the following do not cause peliosis hepatis?
questions.explanation: Analgesics will not cause peliosis hepatis.Peliosis hepatis is an uncommon vascular condition characterized by hemorrhagic dilatation ofthe hepatic sinusoids. Conditions causing peliosis hepatis are:•Bartonella henselae infection, tuberculosis, and human immunodeficiency virus• Use of anabolic steroids• Immunosuppressants such as 6-mercaptopurine, azathioprine, methotrexate, and tamoxifen• X-linked myotubular myopathyBiopsy showing hemorrhagic dilatation:700Often an incidental finding, many patients present without symptoms. Less frequently, patientsmay present with signs more consistent with hepatobiliary pathology such as right upperquadrant pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension.Laboratory studies, such as LFT may or may not demonstrate changes. CT or MRI angiographyoften demonstrates contrast accumulating within the parenchyma itself or the sinusoids. Abiopsy is the best modality to confirm the diagnosis.701
